subject: Home & DIY
title: Arc Faults: Fires from Bad Wiring
description: A fast breakdown of Arc Faults: Fires from Bad Wiring for builders.

hook.text: An electrical arc is a spark jumping a gap in damaged wiring. It burns at 6,000Â°Câ€”hot enough to ignite wood fast.

buildup.text: Arcs happen when wire insulation degrades, nails pierce cables, or connections loosen inside walls over time.

discovery.text: Arc Fault Circuit Interrupters (AFCIs) detect the unique electrical signature of an arc and shut down the circuit.

twist.text: Standard breakers only protect against overcurrentâ€”they ignore arcing entirely. A 1-amp arc can start a fire.

climax.text: AFCIs are now required in bedrooms, living rooms, and hallways in new builds. Older homes have no arc protection.

punchline.text: A spark you can't see at 6,000Â°C inside your wall.

quiz.question: Why can't standard circuit breakers prevent arc-caused fires?
options: They only detect overcurrent, not the low-amperage arcing signature
They respond too slowly to momentary arcs
They're only designed for kitchen and bathroom circuits
